questions.text: A 42-year-old male prisoner is being evaluated for aggressive tendencies and antisocial behavior. Which of the following genotypes is associated with these symptoms?
questions.solution:
XYY genotype is often associated with aggressive tendencies, antisocial, and often, criminal behavior. It is called Jacob’s syndrome.

Option A: XXY genotype is associated with Klinefelter's syndrome.

Option B: XO genotype is associated with Turner's syndrome.

Option C: Triple X syndrome is associated with genotype XXX. It is also called super female.

questions.text: What is the risk of developing Down's syndrome in a baby born to a 45-year-old woman?
questions.solution:
The risk of developing Down’s syndrome in a baby born to a 45-year-old woman is 1 in 50.

The risk of developing of Down's syndrome in a baby born to a 20-year-old woman is around 1 in 3000 and it increases with rising maternal age. It is an autosomal disorder caused by trisomy of chromosome 21.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is not autosomal dominant?
questions.solution:
Ataxia-telangiectasia or Louis-Bar syndrome is an autosomal recessive condition.

Autosomal dominant conditions include:

  • Neurofibromatosis
  • Marfan’s syndrome
  • Retinoblastoma
  • Huntington's chorea
  • Polycystic kidney disease

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect regarding autosomal recessive disorders?

choices.text: Both male and female offspring are affected
Most inborn errors of metabolism have this form of inheritance
It affects more people at a later age than in childhood

questions.solution:
Autosomal recessive disorders usually manifest in childhood or earlier. 

Heterozygotes are unaffected by the disease. When both parents are heterozygous, each offspring (both male and female) has a 1:4 chance of being affected. Examples of autosomal recessive disorders include several inborn errors of metabolism like phenylketonuria, cystic fibrosis, and galactosemia.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy with recurrent hemarthrosis was found to have deficiency of factor VIII. He was adopted and his family history is unknown. What is the inheritance pattern of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of hemophilia A. It is an X-linked recessive disorder.

Hemophilia is of two types:

  • Hemophilia A - due to mutations in the F8 gene leading to factor VIII deficiency 
  • Hemophilia B - due to mutations in the F9 gene leading to factor IX deficiency

Affected children often present with prolonged bleeding after procedures like circumcision or major bleeds like intracranial hemorrhages. When the child begins to walk, bleeding into the joint (hemarthrosis) may occur, causing painful swellings and reddening. 

Laboratory investigations show elevated aPTT, with normal PT and platelet count. It is treated by the administration of factor VIII or factor IX concentrates.

questions.text: A pathologist is examining the peripheral smear of a patient with anemia. Which of the following is incorrect about the epidemiology of this disease?

choices.text: It is prevalent in areas with high frequency of malaria
It is an autosomal dominant disorder
Couples at risk can undergo prenatal testing and diagnosis
It manifests during the first year of life

questions.solution:
The given peripheral smear shows sickling of RBCs, suggestive of sickle cell anemia. It is an autosomal recessive disorder. 

The prevalence is high among Africans. This disorder usually has its onset during the first year of life. Couples at risk can opt for prenatal testing and diagnosis as well.

questions.text: What was the primary goal of the Human Genome Project?

choices.text: To introduce a gene sequence into a cell
To develop new diagnostic techniques for genetic disorders
To determine the sequence of nucleotide base pairs in human DNA
To study the precise genetic composition of specific populations

questions.solution:
The primary goal of the Human Genome Project was to determine the sequence of nucleotide base pairs that make up human DNA and to map all genes from the human genome (20,500 genes).

The project was launched in 1990 and deemed complete in 2003.

questions.text: What is Hardy-Weinberg law related to?
questions.solution:
The Hardy-Weinberg law is related to population genetics. Population genetics is the study of the precise genetic composition of a population and various factors determining the incidence of inherited traits in them. 

Founder effect is a violation to this law. It is due to difference in expression of the genes in founding population. This is responsible for the difference in the distribution of disease in population.

Related Pearl: Hardy-Weinberg Law

  • The Hardy-Weinberg Law is related to population genetics.
  • It is based on the principle founded by G.H. Hardy and Wilhelm Weinberg.
  • The law states that the relative frequencies of each gene allele tends to remain constant from generation to generation in the absence of other evolutionary influences.
  • It is also called the Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium or principle.
  • It is only applicable for infinitely large, static populations which randomly mate.
  • This law fails in the following conditions:
    • Small and dynamic populations
    • Non random or assortative mating
    • Mutations
    • Gene outflow and genetic drift
    • Migration

questions.text: The Hardy-Weinberg law is applicable in populations with which of the following?
questions.solution:
The Hardy-Weinberg law is applicable for infinitely large, static populations with random mating.

questions.text:
Match the following.
Term Definition
1) Positive eugenics      a) Environmental manipulation to enable genes to express themselves
2) Negative eugenics     b) Making phenotypic improvements to humans after birth
3) Euthenics c) Encouraging the breeding of those with desirable phenotypes
4) Euphenics d) Discouraging the breeding of those with undesirable phenotypes
questions.solution:
Positive eugenics encourages the breeding of those with desirable phenotypes.

Negative eugenics discourages the breeding of those with undesirable phenotypes.

Euthenics is the environmental manipulation to enable genes to express themselves.

Euphenics is the science of making phenotypic improvements in humans after birth, generally to affect a problematic genetic condition.

questions.text: A young woman with a family history of beta-thalassemia is planning to marry her first cousin. Which of the following will you recommend for this woman?
questions.solution:
This young woman must be advised to undergo prospective counseling.

It refers to the process explaining to heterozygous individuals the risk of having affected children if they marry another heterozygous individual. It is performed prior to conception.

Retrospective counseling is performed after the genetic disorder has already occurred in the first child.

questions.text: A 40-year-old pregnant woman is planned for amniocentesis. What is the gestational age at which it can be done at the earliest?
questions.solution:
Amniocentesis can be done as early as 14 weeks of gestation.

It refers to the examination of a sample of amniotic fluid to diagnose chromosomal disorders and some metabolic errors. It is indicated in the following cases:

  • Pregnant women aged 35 years or above
  • Family history of:
    • Chromosomal abnormalities
    • Metabolic errors
    • Chromosomal translocation
    • Sex-linked genetic disease

questions.text: What is a Punnett square used for?
questions.solution:
A Punnett square is a diagram used to predict the probability of a particular genotype in an offspring.

It is a standard tool for genetic counselors. The image given below shows a Punnett square.

questions.text: The risk of genetic diseases in consanguineous marriage between first cousins is?
questions.solution:
The risk of genetic diseases in consanguineous marriage between first cousins is 4-8%.

The risk of genetic diseases in non-consanguineous marriage is 2-4%.
